Don't forget - beginning today, September 8, we will operate our curbside meal service at only our elementary school sites.

Students in all grade levels can receive a meal from any of our 23 elementary school sites at no cost. Students are not required to visit their assigned school to receive a meal and will not be asked to provide a student ID number at this time. The curbside meal service will operate Monday through Friday from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. Students will receive a breakfast and a lunch at no cost.

At this time, meals will be provided to all students at no cost through December 31. This is made possible due to an extension from the USDA. Parents are encouraged to visit www.lunchapplication.com to apply for assistance paying for meals after the December 31 extension.

Parents can find more information and videos on how our curbside meal service operates on our reopening website. https://bit.ly/JCPSSchoolNutrition

We look forward to serving our students!

Tonight during a special called session, the Johnston County Board of Education voted to continue operating schools under Plan C for the remainder of the first quarter, which ends on Oct. 15.

Pre-K, K-5, and Self-Contained EC students will not return for face-to-face instruction on Sept. 8, as previously planned. JCCTLA will remain on their current schedule. All other students will continue with virtual learning for the duration of the first quarter.

This decision was made out of an abundance of caution for our students, staff, and families as our county continues to see a rise in COVID-19 cases. We will continue to work with the Johnston County Health Department to determine the safest plan to return students to the classroom. We thank you for your understanding as we continue to navigate this school year.

Thank you and have a good evening.

Johnston County Public Schools has begun posting the number of confirmed, school-related COVID-19 cases that are reported to us by the Johnston County Health Department. This will give families and staff more information about how the pandemic is impacting the school system.

Names and other identifying information, including school/site location, will not be released due to privacy laws and the sensitivity of this information.

Superintendent Dr. Eric Bracy said the dashboard is a result of the Board of Education’s intent to be transparent with the community about the pandemic. Bracy stated, “Like all other districts, JCPS is concerned about the well-being of our students, staff, and parents. This new tool will help our community make decisions based on the data.”

The COVID-19 dashboard will be available on the district’s website at www.johnston.k12.nc.us/dashboard

Below is a message from Johnston County Public Schools Superintendent Dr. Eric Bracy:

Students and Families of the Class of 2020,

While I have been superintendent in Johnston County Public Schools for just a few weeks, I am also the parent of a daughter who is a member of the Class of 2020. l know that this has been a very difficult time for students, parents, and families. Recently, we made the difficult, but safe decision to move forward with the second option from the survey issued in May to hold drive thru/drive in graduation ceremonies.

Our seniors are important to us, and we know that this is not the outcome everyone wanted. But our high school principals have assured me that these ceremonies will be special and a great event for our students and families. Graduation ceremonies have been scheduled at each of our high schools. I wish each of our senior students and families success, safety, and happiness as these students take the next steps in their lives.

Thank you and have a great evening.

Attention parents of 4-year-olds: Are you interested in your child attending a free preschool program? The NC PreK program is designed to provide 4-year-old children with positive early learning experiences that support their development and prepare them for Kindergarten.

NC PreK is free to families. Children must be four years old on or before August 31. Additional criteria for eligibility includes risk factors such as a developmental disability, Limited English Proficiency, educational need, chronic health conditions, and/or reduced family income. Children of active duty military families may also be eligible regardless of income or presence of risk factors.

If you are interested in enrolling your 4-year-old child in a fun and engaging early learning experience, please contact the Partnership For Children at 919-202-0002 or www.pfcjc.org.

Attendees can learn how to apply for positions and more about what Johnston County Public Schools has to offer for new and experienced educators. Interested persons can register for this event by visiting www.johnston.k12.nc.us/jobfair.

In celebration of Black History Month, JCPS is recognizing influential African-Americans that have caused positive change in the history of America. Today we honor Reverend Martin Luther King Jr. Dr. King was a leader in the Civil Rights movement from 1955 until 1968. Dr. King’s techniques were practicing nonviolence and civil disobedience. He was most known for the Montgomery bus boycott in 1955 and the march on Washington in 1963 where he delivered his “I Have a Dream Speech.” Dr. King was assassinated in 1968 in Memphis, TN. He was posthumously awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom and the Congressional Gold Medal. His birthday was established as a federal holiday in 1985.

Dr. King’s tireless work for equality has never stopped and still continues today by those he influenced.

Today we will honor and remember Dr. King by sharing some of his most influential quotes throughout the day.

"Darkness cannot drive out darkness; only light can do that. Hate cannot drive out hate; only love can do that."

The Johnston County Board of Education has hired the North Carolina School Boards Association to help facilitate its search for the next superintendent of JCPS. The board is seeking direct input from interested students, parents, members of the community, and staff to help shape the search process and to assist in defining the qualities and characteristics desired in the next JCPS superintendent. The board invites students, parents, and other members of the community to participate in a community survey that can be accessed and completed online by visiting https://www.johnston.k12.nc.us/survey.

All surveys must be completed by Wednesday, Feb. 26. Results will be compiled, summarized, and presented by NCSBA at the regularly scheduled board meeting on Tuesday, March 10.

You can read more about the superintendent search and ways you can contribute by visiting our website.

post_text: Congratulations to the Meadow School for winning the state championship in Middle Grades Livestock Judging! Students on the team are Ty Strickland, Riley Adams, Anna Wells, and Chase Massengill. Way to go!!
shared_text:
Meadow School
December 2, 2019 at 3:45 PM ·

Tuesday our Middle grades team of Ty Strickland, Riley Adams, Anna Wells, and Chase Massengill won the state championship in Middle grades livestock judging. Anna was 4th high score in state of over 80 members. Great job.

Our Jr team competing against up to 10th graders finished 39 out of 78 teams. Haley Bass was team high scorer. Other members were Tyler Beasley, Ben Grantham, and Parker Denning.

The Senior team did amazing too. They were 47 out of 109 teams up to seniors. They were the highest ranked middle school in the senior division. Members were Emily Pope, Dawson Creech, Andrew Lockamy, and Thomas Edwards.

Seniors in the AVID program at Smithfield-Selma High outperformed their peers across North Carolina and the nation. Newly released college-readiness data shows the success of the 2019 graduating class of students participating in the district's AVID program. According to the AVID Center, last year 96% of Smithfield-Selma High seniors participating in AVID completed a FAFSA application, compared to the national rate of 61%. Likewise, 100% of AVID students applied to a four-year college, and 96% were accepted. Congratulations to the Smithfield-Selma High AVID students in the Class of 2019!! We are so proud of you!

post_text: Several North Johnston High juniors and seniors recently visited Miller-Motte College to learn more about their Dental Hygiene program! Students had the opportunity to talk with faculty members and even see a presentation from current students. What a great opportunity for our students!
shared_text:
North Johnston High School
November 20, 2019 at 5:47 PM ·

Thirteen NJHS juniors and seniors visited Miller-Motte recently to discover information about their Dental Hygiene program. Students were accompanied by chaperones Sharif Ewais, our Post-secondary Advisor, and Lola Lippert, our Career Development Coordinator.

Mr. Ewais commented, "Students had a blast touring the Dental Hygiene Program at Miller-Motte College today! They were able to speak with faculty members and were even allowed to sit through a presentation from current students."

A special thanks to Mr. Ewais for arranging the trip and to Mrs. Lippert for transporting our students safely!

The Johnston County Public Schools Facility Services Department will be accepting sealed bids for items which have been declared surplus by the Johnston County Board of Education.

The purpose of a surplus sale is to sell stored furniture or equipment that has reached its usefulness to the school system, whether through age or disrepair.

These items may be previewed on Thursday, December 12, 2019 from 12:00 - 4:00 PM at Facility Services, located at 601 A West Market Street, Smithfield, NC.

Bids will be received on Friday, December 13, 2019 from 8:00 AM. - 12 PM, at which time all bids will be opened and the high bidder will be notified by phone that day by 5:00 PM. Items will be available for pick up Monday, December 16, 2019 from 8:00 AM - 3:30 PM. There will be no early or late pick up and payment will be received by cash or check only.

For questions and additional information please call 919-934-2021 ext. 7003.

More - http://bit.ly/JCPSSurplusSale
